vocabulary.def: The ability of a system to handle a growing amount of work.
The time delay between a cause and the effect.
The amount of data moved successfully across a network.
The proportion of time a system is functional and working.
The maximum rate of data transfer across a given path.

grammar.note: Use 'be + past participle'. Common in tech docs: 'Data is encrypted...'
Used for instructions. Example: 'Run the script to deploy...'

tech_spotlight.title: Edge Computing
tech_spotlight.detail: Processing data closer to the source to reduce latency, crucial for BytePlus RTC services.

vocabulary.def: The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction for its transfer, often measured in milliseconds.
The capability of a system, network, or process to handle a growing amount of work, or its potential to be enlarged to accommodate that growth.
A property of certain operations whereby they can be applied multiple times without changing the result beyond the initial application.
A hardware or software component that stores data so that future requests for that data can be served faster.
Occurring at different times; not synchronized, often referring to operations that do not block the execution of other tasks.

grammar.note: Use 'has/have + past participle' to describe actions that started in the past and continue to the present, or have relevance to the present. Example: 'We have implemented caching to reduce latency.'
Use 'if + present simple, will + base verb' to talk about real and possible situations in the future. Example: 'If we improve scalability, the system will handle more users.'

tech_spotlight.title: Microservices Architecture
tech_spotlight.detail: Microservices architecture is an approach where a single application is composed of many loosely coupled and independently deployable smaller services. Each service runs a unique process and communicates through a well-defined, lightweight mechanism to serve a business goal.

scenario_dialogue.speaker: Senior Dev
scenario_dialogue.text: We need to reduce the latency in our API responses. Have you considered implementing a cache?

scenario_dialogue.speaker: Willbazinga
scenario_dialogue.text: Yes, I've been looking into caching strategies. I think an asynchronous caching layer could help improve scalability.

scenario_dialogue.speaker: Senior Dev
scenario_dialogue.text: Good idea. Also, ensure the cache operations are idempotent to avoid side effects on repeated requests.

scenario_dialogue.speaker: Willbazinga
scenario_dialogue.text: Understood. I'll design the cache to be idempotent and test it with various load scenarios to ensure it handles asynchronous calls efficiently.
